The humid New Orleans air clung to Chief Dagbjort Magnusson's uniform like a second skin as he walked through the French Quarter that Tuesday morning in late August. Sweat beaded on his forehead despite the early hour, and he found himself longing for the cooler climate of his native Minnesota. Twenty-three years on the force had taught him to read the city's moods, and today something felt different. The usual cacophony of street musicians, tourists, and vendors seemed muted, as if the city itself was holding its breath.

Dagbjort had earned his position through a combination of relentless determination and an uncanny ability to solve cases that left other detectives scratching their heads. At fifty-two, his sandy hair had begun to show streaks of silver, but his pale blue eyes remained as sharp as the day he'd graduated from the police academy. His colleagues respected him, though few claimed to truly know him. He kept his personal life compartmentalized, a habit formed during his tumultuous divorce fifteen years prior.

The only escape from the pressures of running one of the most challenging police departments in the South came on Saturday mornings at Audubon Park Golf Course. It wasn't the most prestigious course in the city, but it offered something that the exclusive country clubs could not: anonymity. Here, among the ancient oak trees draped in Spanish moss, Dagbjort could forget about murder rates and political pressures for a few precious hours.

On this particular morning, as he approached the first tee, Dagbjort noticed a new face among the regular caddies. The young man couldn't have been more than twenty-five, with dark hair that curled slightly at the edges and warm brown eyes that seemed to take in everything around him. He stood with the easy confidence of someone comfortable in his own skin, chatting with the other caddies while occasionally glancing toward the clubhouse.

"Morning, Chief," called out Mickey, the head caddy who had been working the course since before Dagbjort started playing there. "Got someone new I'd like you to meet. This here's Cameron Thibodaux. Just moved down from Shreveport, looking to pick up some regular work."

Cameron stepped forward with a genuine smile that immediately put Dagbjort at ease. "Pleasure to meet you, Chief Magnusson. Mickey tells me you play every Saturday morning, rain or shine. I respect that kind of dedication."

There was something in the young man's voice, a slight drawl mixed with genuine enthusiasm, that caught Dagbjort's attention. Most people, upon learning his profession, either became overly deferential or uncomfortably distant. Cameron seemed refreshingly unaffected by the revelation.

"Just Dag when we're on the course," he replied, extending his hand. Cameron's grip was firm without being aggressive, calloused in a way that spoke of honest work. "You play yourself?"

"Some," Cameron admitted with a self-deprecating grin. "Not well enough to embarrass myself in front of a regular, but I know the game. Been caddying since I was fourteen back home."

Dagbjort found himself studying the young man's face as they talked. There was an openness there that he rarely encountered in his line of work, a quality that seemed almost anachronistic in today's cynical world. When Cameron asked if he could carry Dagbjort's bag that morning, the chief found himself nodding before he'd consciously made the decision.

The first few holes passed in comfortable conversation. Cameron proved to be an excellent caddy, always positioning himself correctly, keeping the clubs clean, and offering subtle course management suggestions when asked. More importantly, he seemed to understand when to talk and when to let the silence speak for itself. By the time they reached the par-three seventh hole, Dagbjort realized he was enjoying himself more than he had in months.

"You mentioned Shreveport," Dagbjort said as he lined up his tee shot. "What brought you down to New Orleans?"

Cameron was quiet for a moment, adjusting the flag stick they'd pulled from the hole. "Change of scenery, mostly. Sometimes you get to a point where you need to see what else is out there, you know? My mama always said New Orleans was a city that could change a person, for better or worse."

The shot sailed true, landing twelve feet from the pin. Cameron handed Dagbjort his putter with an approving nod. "Mama sounds like a wise woman."

"She was," Cameron replied, his voice carrying a note of wistfulness. "Passed two years ago. Cancer. After that, staying in Shreveport felt like living in a museum of memories."

Dagbjort lined up his putt, but found his concentration affected by the raw honesty in Cameron's voice. The ball rolled past the hole, stopping three feet beyond. As they walked toward the ball, he found himself sharing something he rarely discussed with anyone.

"Lost my father when I was about your age. Heart attack. One day he was there, teaching me how to change the oil in my truck, next day he was gone. I understand about the museum of memories."

Cameron looked at him with something approaching surprise, as if he hadn't expected such personal revelation from the reserved police chief. "Does it get easier?"

"Different," Dagbjort said, sinking the short putt. "Not easier, just different. You learn to carry them with you instead of feeling like you're leaving them behind."

The conversation shifted to lighter topics as they continued their round, but something had changed between them. The professional distance that Dagbjort maintained with most people had somehow dissolved without his noticing. By the time they finished on the eighteenth green, he found himself looking forward to their next round together.

"Same time next week?" Cameron asked as they walked toward the clubhouse.

"Wouldn't miss it," Dagbjort replied, meaning it more than he cared to admit.

Over the following weeks, Saturday mornings became the highlight of Dagbjort's week. Cameron proved to be not only an excellent caddy but also surprisingly good company. Their conversations ranged from the mundane to the profound, touching on everything from local politics to philosophy to their shared love of old movies. Dagbjort discovered that Cameron had studied literature at Louisiana Tech before dropping out when his mother became ill, and that he wrote poetry in his spare time."Poetry?" Dagbjort asked one particularly humid Saturday in September, as they walked down the tree-lined fairway of the fourteenth hole. The morning mist was just beginning to lift from the grass, creating an almost ethereal atmosphere around them. "Can't say I've met many poets in my line of work. Unless you count the creative fiction some suspects come up with during interrogations."

Cameron laughed, a warm sound that seemed to blend naturally with the gentle rustling of Spanish moss overhead. "I suppose that's a different kind of creative writing altogether. Mine's mostly about places and people, trying to capture moments that might otherwise slip away unnoticed. Nothing too fancy or academic, just observations about life down here in Louisiana." He paused to clean Dagbjort's seven-iron with practiced efficiency before adding, "I'd probably bore you to tears with most of it."

The chief found himself genuinely curious about this aspect of Cameron's life, though he couldn't quite explain why. In his professional world, everything was concrete, measurable, based on evidence and facts. The idea of someone dedicating time to capturing ephemeral moments in verse struck him as both foreign and oddly appealing. "I doubt that very much. Takes a different kind of courage to put your thoughts down on paper like that, knowing someone else might read them and judge them."

"Courage or foolishness," Cameron replied with that self-deprecating smile Dagbjort had come to recognize. "Sometimes it's hard to tell the difference. My mama used to say that writing was like praying, except you weren't sure if anyone was listening on the other end." He handed Dagbjort the club and stepped back to give him room for the shot. "She kept all my poems in a shoebox under her bed, even the terrible ones I wrote in high school about broken hearts and the unfairness of small-town life."

Dagbjort took his stance, but found his attention divided between the shot and the conversation. There was something in Cameron's voice when he spoke about his mother that resonated deeply, a mixture of love and loss that the chief recognized from his own experience with grief. The ball sailed toward the green, landing softly near the pin in what was probably his best approach shot of the morning. "Sounds like she was proud of you," he said, shouldering his bag as they began walking again.

"She was proud of all her children, sometimes to a fault," Cameron admitted, his expression growing thoughtful. "I have two older sisters, both married with kids, both still living within ten miles of where we grew up. They never understood why I needed to leave, why I couldn't just settle down with some nice local girl and take over daddy's auto repair shop like everyone expected." The words carried no bitterness, just a quiet acceptance of the fundamental differences that sometimes exist within families.

As they approached the green, Dagbjort found himself wondering about those expectations, about the courage it must have taken for Cameron to choose uncertainty over the comfortable predictability of staying home. In his own life, moving from Minnesota to Louisiana had been driven more by professional opportunity than personal choice, but he remembered the feeling of cutting ties with familiar places and people. "Sometimes the people who love us most have the hardest time understanding what we need to grow," he offered, surprised by his own willingness to engage in such personal territory.

Cameron nodded as he tended the flag, his movements economical and precise. "Exactly. They weren't wrong to want security and stability for me, but they couldn't see that staying would have been a different kind of death. Not dramatic or tragic, just a slow fading into someone I was never meant to be." He pulled the flag as Dagbjort's putt rolled toward the hole, stopping just inches from the cup. "Nice read on that green, by the way. This course has some tricky undulations that most people miss."

The easy transition from philosophical discussion to golf commentary was something Dagbjort had come to appreciate about Cameron's conversational style. The young man seemed equally comfortable with both the profound and the mundane, never forcing either but allowing conversations to flow naturally between different levels of depth. It was a rare quality, one that the chief found increasingly valuable as their Saturday morning rounds became an established routine.

By October, their weekly golf games had developed their own rhythm and traditions. They would meet at seven-thirty sharp, regardless of weather conditions, and spend the first few holes catching up on the week's events. Cameron would ask general questions about Dagbjort's work, always respectful of confidentiality boundaries, while sharing stories from his various part-time jobs around the city. He had quickly discovered that caddying alone wouldn't cover his expenses, so he supplemented his income with bartending shifts at a quiet restaurant in the Garden District and occasional landscaping work for wealthy families in the area.

"You're building quite a network," Dagbjort observed one morning as they prepared to tee off on the challenging par-four eighth hole. The autumn air carried a slight chill that provided welcome relief from the oppressive heat of summer, though by Minnesota standards it was still remarkably warm. "Between the golf course, the restaurant, and the landscaping jobs, you must be meeting half the city."

Cameron selected a driver from Dagbjort's bag and handed it over with a grin. "New Orleans isn't as big as it seems once you start paying attention to who knows whom. The bartending job has been particularly educational - you'd be amazed what people will tell a stranger when they think he's not really listening." He positioned himself to watch the shot, his stance relaxed but attentive. "Nothing criminal or anything like that, just the usual human drama of who's sleeping with whom, who's having money troubles, whose marriage is falling apart behind closed doors."

The observation struck Dagbjort as remarkably astute for someone so young. In his line of work, understanding the hidden connections and unspoken tensions within a community was essential, but it had taken him years to develop that kind of social awareness. Cameron seemed to possess it naturally, along with the wisdom to treat such knowledge with appropriate discretion. "Sounds like you've got the makings of a detective yourself," he said, only half-joking as he addressed the ball.The shot hooked slightly left, landing in the rough near a cluster of oak trees. Cameron shouldered the bag without comment, though Dagbjort caught the slight shake of his head that suggested the young man had read the shot's trajectory before the ball had even landed. As they walked toward the wayward ball, Cameron's expression grew more serious, as if the casual mention of detective work had triggered some deeper consideration.

"I've thought about law enforcement, actually," Cameron admitted, stepping carefully around a partially buried sprinkler head. "Not necessarily police work, but maybe something in the legal field. When I was helping take care of mama during her illness, I had to navigate so much bureaucracy, so many systems that seemed designed to wear people down rather than help them. It made me realize how much power comes from understanding how institutions really work, not just how they're supposed to work on paper." He paused to examine Dagbjort's ball, which had come to rest behind a thick root. "This is going to require some creativity. You've got about a hundred and thirty yards to the pin, but that root is going to make a clean strike difficult."

Dagbjort studied the lie while processing Cameron's words. The young man's observation about institutional power was surprisingly sophisticated, revealing a depth of understanding that went beyond his years or apparent experience. It also explained something that Dagbjort had noticed but hadn't been able to articulate - Cameron's unusual comfort level around authority figures, his ability to engage with people from different social and economic backgrounds without changing his fundamental manner or speech patterns. "Sounds like your mother's illness taught you more than just poetry about the human condition," he said, selecting a pitching wedge and taking a few practice swings to gauge the best angle of approach.

"Mama was a fighter, but she was also practical. She made sure I understood that being smart wasn't enough if you didn't know how to navigate the world as it actually exists rather than as you wish it would be." Cameron's voice carried that familiar note of affection mixed with loss, but also something else - a kind of steely determination that Dagbjort recognized in his own approach to difficult cases. "She'd probably get a kick out of knowing I'm spending my Saturday mornings with the chief of police, picking his brain about how the justice system works from the inside. Though she'd also remind me that every person has a story that goes deeper than their job title or public reputation."

The comment was made lightly, but Dagbjort sensed layers of meaning beneath Cameron's casual tone. There was an acknowledgment of the professional distance that typically surrounded his position, but also a gentle challenge to it. Over the past several weeks, Cameron had demonstrated an unusual ability to see past the uniform and the authority it represented, engaging with Dagbjort as simply another person struggling with life's complexities. It was a rare gift, one that the chief had learned to value precisely because it was so uncommon in his daily experience.

The wedge shot cleared the root cleanly, though it landed short of the green in a sandy area that would require delicate touch for the next approach. As they walked toward the ball, Dagbjort found himself reflecting on how much his Saturday mornings had changed since Cameron had begun caddying for him. What had once been solitary meditation time, a chance to escape from the pressures of leadership and public scrutiny, had evolved into something richer and more complex. The conversation, the easy camaraderie, the sense of genuine connection with another person - these had become as important as the golf itself, perhaps more so.

"Your mother sounds like she raised you to think independently," Dagbjort observed, examining his next shot. The ball sat in a slight depression, requiring him to adjust his stance to ensure clean contact. "That's not always an easy thing for parents to do, especially in smaller communities where conformity tends to be valued over individual expression. Takes courage to encourage your children to question authority and think for themselves."

Cameron's smile was tinged with both pride and sadness as he cleaned a sand wedge and handed it over. "She had her own struggles with small-town expectations, believe me. Got pregnant with my oldest sister when she was nineteen, married daddy because it was what everyone expected her to do, spent the next twenty-five years trying to convince herself that other people's definitions of happiness were the same as her own." The honesty in his voice was matter-of-fact rather than bitter, as if he had made peace with the complexities of his family's history. "By the time I came along, she'd learned that love sometimes means giving people permission to disappoint you, to choose paths that don't make sense from the outside but feel necessary from the inside."

The observation resonated deeply with Dagbjort's own experience, both as a parent during his brief marriage and as a son who had disappointed his own family by leaving Minnesota for what they considered the questionable adventure of Southern law enforcement. The sand wedge connected cleanly, sending the ball in a high arc that landed softly on the green and rolled to within six feet of the pin. It was perhaps his best recovery shot in weeks, and he suspected that the quality of the conversation was somehow contributing to the improved focus and rhythm of his game.

"Sounds like wisdom earned through experience rather than just inherited through tradition," he said, pulling the club from the sand and wiping it clean before handing it back to Cameron. "That's the kind of understanding that can't be taught in schools or learned from books. Has to be lived through, survived, integrated into how you see the world." The words carried more weight than he had intended, revealing perhaps more about his own journey toward understanding than he typically shared with anyone.

As they approached the green, Cameron's expression grew thoughtful, and Dagbjort could see him processing not just the conversation but the growing familiarity between them. There was something almost tentative in the young man's manner, as if he were testing the boundaries of their developing friendship while remaining respectful of the professional and generational differences that separated them. It was a delicate balance, one that required emotional intelligence and social awareness beyond Cameron's apparent years.

"I've been thinking about what you said a few weeks ago, about learning to carry people with you instead of feeling like you're leaving them behind," Cameron said, his voice quiet enough that it wouldn't disturb any nearby golfers. "I'm starting to understand that maybe the best way to honor mama's memory isn't to recreate the life she thought she wanted for me, but to live with the kind of courage and authenticity she never quite managed to claim for herself." It was the expression of someone who had been carrying a burden of doubt for longer than he cared to admit, finally finding the courage to voice fears that had been gnawing at him in quiet moments.

"I was hoping it would feel this way, but you never really know how someone's private environment will affect the dynamic between you until you're actually sharing it together," he replied, raising his wine glass in a small gesture of celebration that acknowledged the success of their first evening alone together. You're exactly the same person here that you are on the golf course, just more relaxed and open, which suggests that the authenticity I've been appreciating in our friendship is really who you are rather than just a version of yourself that you present in certain circumstances."

The humid New Orleans air clung to Chief Dagbjort Magnusson's uniform like a second skin as he walked through the French Quarter that Tuesday morning in late August. Sweat beaded on his forehead despite the early hour, and he found himself longing for the cooler climate of his native Minnesota. Twenty-three years on the force had taught him to read the city's moods, and today something felt different. The usual cacophony of street musicians, tourists, and vendors seemed muted, as if the city itself was holding its breath.

Dagbjort had earned his position through a combination of relentless determination and an uncanny ability to solve cases that left other detectives scratching their heads. At fifty-two, his sandy hair had begun to show streaks of silver, but his pale blue eyes remained as sharp as the day he'd graduated from the police academy. His colleagues respected him, though few claimed to truly know him. He kept his personal life compartmentalized, a habit formed during his tumultuous divorce fifteen years prior.

The only escape from the pressures of running one of the most challenging police departments in the South came on Saturday mornings at Audubon Park Golf Course. It wasn't the most prestigious course in the city, but it offered something that the exclusive country clubs could not: anonymity. Here, among the ancient oak trees draped in Spanish moss, Dagbjort could forget about murder rates and political pressures for a few precious hours.

On this particular morning, as he approached the first tee, Dagbjort noticed a new face among the regular caddies. The young man couldn't have been more than twenty-five, with dark hair that curled slightly at the edges and warm brown eyes that seemed to take in everything around him. He stood with the easy confidence of someone comfortable in his own skin, chatting with the other caddies while occasionally glancing toward the clubhouse.

"Morning, Chief," called out Mickey, the head caddy who had been working the course since before Dagbjort started playing there. "Got someone new I'd like you to meet. This here's Cameron Thibodaux. Just moved down from Shreveport, looking to pick up some regular work."

Cameron stepped forward with a genuine smile that immediately put Dagbjort at ease. "Pleasure to meet you, Chief Magnusson. Mickey tells me you play every Saturday morning, rain or shine. I respect that kind of dedication."

There was something in the young man's voice, a slight drawl mixed with genuine enthusiasm, that caught Dagbjort's attention. Most people, upon learning his profession, either became overly deferential or uncomfortably distant. Cameron seemed refreshingly unaffected by the revelation.

"Just Dag when we're on the course," he replied, extending his hand. Cameron's grip was firm without being aggressive, calloused in a way that spoke of honest work. "You play yourself?"

"Some," Cameron admitted with a self-deprecating grin. "Not well enough to embarrass myself in front of a regular, but I know the game. Been caddying since I was fourteen back home."

Dagbjort found himself studying the young man's face as they talked. There was an openness there that he rarely encountered in his line of work, a quality that seemed almost anachronistic in today's cynical world. When Cameron asked if he could carry Dagbjort's bag that morning, the chief found himself nodding before he'd consciously made the decision.

The first few holes passed in comfortable conversation. Cameron proved to be an excellent caddy, always positioning himself correctly, keeping the clubs clean, and offering subtle course management suggestions when asked. More importantly, he seemed to understand when to talk and when to let the silence speak for itself. By the time they reached the par-three seventh hole, Dagbjort realized he was enjoying himself more than he had in months.

"You mentioned Shreveport," Dagbjort said as he lined up his tee shot. "What brought you down to New Orleans?"

Cameron was quiet for a moment, adjusting the flag stick they'd pulled from the hole. "Change of scenery, mostly. Sometimes you get to a point where you need to see what else is out there, you know? My mama always said New Orleans was a city that could change a person, for better or worse."

The shot sailed true, landing twelve feet from the pin. Cameron handed Dagbjort his putter with an approving nod. "Mama sounds like a wise woman."

"She was," Cameron replied, his voice carrying a note of wistfulness. "Passed two years ago. Cancer. After that, staying in Shreveport felt like living in a museum of memories."

Dagbjort lined up his putt, but found his concentration affected by the raw honesty in Cameron's voice. The ball rolled past the hole, stopping three feet beyond. As they walked toward the ball, he found himself sharing something he rarely discussed with anyone.

"Lost my father when I was about your age. Heart attack. One day he was there, teaching me how to change the oil in my truck, next day he was gone. I understand about the museum of memories."

Cameron looked at him with something approaching surprise, as if he hadn't expected such personal revelation from the reserved police chief. "Does it get easier?"

"Different," Dagbjort said, sinking the short putt. "Not easier, just different. You learn to carry them with you instead of feeling like you're leaving them behind."

The conversation shifted to lighter topics as they continued their round, but something had changed between them. The professional distance that Dagbjort maintained with most people had somehow dissolved without his noticing. By the time they finished on the eighteenth green, he found himself looking forward to their next round together.

"Same time next week?" Cameron asked as they walked toward the clubhouse.

"Wouldn't miss it," Dagbjort replied, meaning it more than he cared to admit.

Over the following weeks, Saturday mornings became the highlight of Dagbjort's week. Cameron proved to be not only an excellent caddy but also surprisingly good company. Their conversations ranged from the mundane to the profound, touching on everything from local politics to philosophy to their shared love of old movies. Dagbjort discovered that Cameron had studied literature at Louisiana Tech before dropping out when his mother became ill, and that he wrote poetry in his spare time.

"Poetry?" Dagbjort asked one particularly humid Saturday in September, as they walked down the tree-lined fairway of the fourteenth hole. The morning mist was just beginning to lift from the grass, creating an almost ethereal atmosphere around them. "Can't say I've met many poets in my line of work. Unless you count the creative fiction some suspects come up with during interrogations."

Cameron laughed, a warm sound that seemed to blend naturally with the gentle rustling of Spanish moss overhead. "I suppose that's a different kind of creative writing altogether. Mine's mostly about places and people, trying to capture moments that might otherwise slip away unnoticed. Nothing too fancy or academic, just observations about life down here in Louisiana." He paused to clean Dagbjort's seven-iron with practiced efficiency before adding, "I'd probably bore you to tears with most of it."

The chief found himself genuinely curious about this aspect of Cameron's life, though he couldn't quite explain why. In his professional world, everything was concrete, measurable, based on evidence and facts. The idea of someone dedicating time to capturing ephemeral moments in verse struck him as both foreign and oddly appealing. "I doubt that very much. Takes a different kind of courage to put your thoughts down on paper like that, knowing someone else might read them and judge them."

"Courage or foolishness," Cameron replied with that self-deprecating smile Dagbjort had come to recognize. "Sometimes it's hard to tell the difference. My mama used to say that writing was like praying, except you weren't sure if anyone was listening on the other end." He handed Dagbjort the club and stepped back to give him room for the shot. "She kept all my poems in a shoebox under her bed, even the terrible ones I wrote in high school about broken hearts and the unfairness of small-town life."

Dagbjort took his stance, but found his attention divided between the shot and the conversation. There was something in Cameron's voice when he spoke about his mother that resonated deeply, a mixture of love and loss that the chief recognized from his own experience with grief. The ball sailed toward the green, landing softly near the pin in what was probably his best approach shot of the morning. "Sounds like she was proud of you," he said, shouldering his bag as they began walking again.

"She was proud of all her children, sometimes to a fault," Cameron admitted, his expression growing thoughtful. "I have two older sisters, both married with kids, both still living within ten miles of where we grew up. They never understood why I needed to leave, why I couldn't just settle down with some nice local girl and take over daddy's auto repair shop like everyone expected." The words carried no bitterness, just a quiet acceptance of the fundamental differences that sometimes exist within families.

As they approached the green, Dagbjort found himself wondering about those expectations, about the courage it must have taken for Cameron to choose uncertainty over the comfortable predictability of staying home. In his own life, moving from Minnesota to Louisiana had been driven more by professional opportunity than personal choice, but he remembered the feeling of cutting ties with familiar places and people. "Sometimes the people who love us most have the hardest time understanding what we need to grow," he offered, surprised by his own willingness to engage in such personal territory.

Cameron nodded as he tended the flag, his movements economical and precise. "Exactly. They weren't wrong to want security and stability for me, but they couldn't see that staying would have been a different kind of death. Not dramatic or tragic, just a slow fading into someone I was never meant to be." He pulled the flag as Dagbjort's putt rolled toward the hole, stopping just inches from the cup. "Nice read on that green, by the way. This course has some tricky undulations that most people miss."

The easy transition from philosophical discussion to golf commentary was something Dagbjort had come to appreciate about Cameron's conversational style. The young man seemed equally comfortable with both the profound and the mundane, never forcing either but allowing conversations to flow naturally between different levels of depth. It was a rare quality, one that the chief found increasingly valuable as their Saturday morning rounds became an established routine.

By October, their weekly golf games had developed their own rhythm and traditions. They would meet at seven-thirty sharp, regardless of weather conditions, and spend the first few holes catching up on the week's events. Cameron would ask general questions about Dagbjort's work, always respectful of confidentiality boundaries, while sharing stories from his various part-time jobs around the city. He had quickly discovered that caddying alone wouldn't cover his expenses, so he supplemented his income with bartending shifts at a quiet restaurant in the Garden District and occasional landscaping work for wealthy families in the area.

"You're building quite a network," Dagbjort observed one morning as they prepared to tee off on the challenging par-four eighth hole. The autumn air carried a slight chill that provided welcome relief from the oppressive heat of summer, though by Minnesota standards it was still remarkably warm. "Between the golf course, the restaurant, and the landscaping jobs, you must be meeting half the city."

Cameron selected a driver from Dagbjort's bag and handed it over with a grin. "New Orleans isn't as big as it seems once you start paying attention to who knows whom. The bartending job has been particularly educational - you'd be amazed what people will tell a stranger when they think he's not really listening." He positioned himself to watch the shot, his stance relaxed but attentive. "Nothing criminal or anything like that, just the usual human drama of who's sleeping with whom, who's having money troubles, whose marriage is falling apart behind closed doors."

The observation struck Dagbjort as remarkably astute for someone so young. In his line of work, understanding the hidden connections and unspoken tensions within a community was essential, but it had taken him years to develop that kind of social awareness. Cameron seemed to possess it naturally, along with the wisdom to treat such knowledge with appropriate discretion. "Sounds like you've got the makings of a detective yourself," he said, only half-joking as he addressed the ball.

The shot hooked slightly left, landing in the rough near a cluster of oak trees. Cameron shouldered the bag without comment, though Dagbjort caught the slight shake of his head that suggested the young man had read the shot's trajectory before the ball had even landed. As they walked toward the wayward ball, Cameron's expression grew more serious, as if the casual mention of detective work had triggered some deeper consideration.

"I've thought about law enforcement, actually," Cameron admitted, stepping carefully around a partially buried sprinkler head. "Not necessarily police work, but maybe something in the legal field. When I was helping take care of mama during her illness, I had to navigate so much bureaucracy, so many systems that seemed designed to wear people down rather than help them. It made me realize how much power comes from understanding how institutions really work, not just how they're supposed to work on paper." He paused to examine Dagbjort's ball, which had come to rest behind a thick root. "This is going to require some creativity. You've got about a hundred and thirty yards to the pin, but that root is going to make a clean strike difficult."

Dagbjort studied the lie while processing Cameron's words. The young man's observation about institutional power was surprisingly sophisticated, revealing a depth of understanding that went beyond his years or apparent experience. It also explained something that Dagbjort had noticed but hadn't been able to articulate - Cameron's unusual comfort level around authority figures, his ability to engage with people from different social and economic backgrounds without changing his fundamental manner or speech patterns. "Sounds like your mother's illness taught you more than just poetry about the human condition," he said, selecting a pitching wedge and taking a few practice swings to gauge the best angle of approach.

"Mama was a fighter, but she was also practical. She made sure I understood that being smart wasn't enough if you didn't know how to navigate the world as it actually exists rather than as you wish it would be." Cameron's voice carried that familiar note of affection mixed with loss, but also something else - a kind of steely determination that Dagbjort recognized in his own approach to difficult cases. "She'd probably get a kick out of knowing I'm spending my Saturday mornings with the chief of police, picking his brain about how the justice system works from the inside. Though she'd also remind me that every person has a story that goes deeper than their job title or public reputation."

The comment was made lightly, but Dagbjort sensed layers of meaning beneath Cameron's casual tone. There was an acknowledgment of the professional distance that typically surrounded his position, but also a gentle challenge to it. Over the past several weeks, Cameron had demonstrated an unusual ability to see past the uniform and the authority it represented, engaging with Dagbjort as simply another person struggling with life's complexities.
